Comment: This particular slide actually started months earlier in the immigration system. The Supreme Court determined that there is no right to appeal a government decision made by immigration officials.  A US citizen woman was petitioning for her spouse to receive a green card but it was denied because USCIS believed his tattoos to be gang-related (are we sensing a theme here with US immigration and tattoos?). The couple had very compelling evidence that the tattoos were not gang-related, but the Supreme Court determined that there is no right to judicial review of government decisions.  Most Americans hand wave this away as "why should immigrants expect to have rights" but ignore the fact that it's not the immigrant's rights being violated, it is the US sponsor's. Vast majority of immigration visas can't be requested by the beneficiary, it must be done by a US sponsor (like a spouse, relative, employer) who petitions the government on the immigrant's behalf.  And the upshot is that there's no recourse for a decision the government makes either in error or punitively.  [https://www.globalimmigrationblog.com/2024/07/supreme-court-reaffirms-federal-courts-lack-authority-to-review-visa-denials/](https://www.globalimmigrationblog.com/2024/07/supreme-court-reaffirms-federal-courts-lack-authority-to-review-visa-denials/)
